posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: what file system should I format a 1tb SSD that's meant to be readable and writeable for both windows and linux? Would exFAT be alright for that? It'd be used mostly for video files, games and torrenting in general

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302319
>Would exFAT be alright for that?
Yes. But bear in mind it has no permissions or encryption.
Another option is NTFS, Linux NTFS is okay, and you can map your windows users and linux users together [1], giving you working "My Documents" and stuff that actually keeps other people out.


[1] https://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/trusty/man8/ntfs-3g.usermap.8.html

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302322
>NTFS
you can write files on NTFS drives on linux? I used Linux Mint a year or so ago and it could read NTFS I used on windows but couldn't write to them or modify them in any way from what I remember.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302342
Later Linux kernels got improvements in the NTFS driver so it works fine now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302436
>>1302342
It defaults to mounting read-only because it lacks confidence in its own work and sets the "filesystem needs chkdsk" flag on every partition it writes to. So you'll see Windows go "this partition might be damaged and needs checked" every time you boot. But other than that, it's fine.

posts.sub: Poor quality of Sky Girls fansub releases
posts.com:
Sky Girls (2007) has two fansubs out there that I know of, [AK] and [Taedium].
Both look bad, though Taedium looks a little better. I don't know the technical terms to describe how they look bad - blurry, low res looking, noisy (?), just generally shitty.
So, I'm wondering: is the issue with the source DVDs, or could these have used an inferior secondhand source, some shitty old rip from the dark ages with degraded quality?
If the latter - if the pure DVD source is better than these fansub releases - I would like to buy the DVDs (they aren't cheap) and make a new, better one myself.
As I'd like to avoid shelling out money for the DVDs needlessly, can someone with more video know-how than me take a look at the [AK] and [Taedium] releases and see what you think? Is there a better source on the DVDs just waiting to be brought to light or not?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302380
>I don't know the technical terms to describe how they look bad - blurry, low res looking, noisy (?), just generally shitty.
Just to check, how old were you in 2007?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302380
Anyways, there's a DVD rip on anidex. If you want to talk about specific files, please refer to them unambiguously, i.e. by CRC32 or ed2k hash.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302384
>Anyways, there's a DVD rip on anidex
That's the Taedium release.
Which, inexplicably, lacks the next episode previews in all episodes, as an aside. [AK] has them. That's another oddity that makes me question the integrity of the Taedium release in general.
I found this discussion of another [Taedium] DVD rip from the same year as their Sky Girls release:
https://anidb.net/forum/thread/8293
If there is some truth to those comments, I feel I may be on the right track here.

posts.com:
>>1301933
It might be that you didn't block updates and the phone tried to auto update into an incompatible version and corrupted the launcher in the process. Hopefully it also didn't lock the bootloader or things might be bad.

Try flashing back the default fastboot room using the official tool. First use the Mi Unlocker to check the phone status and try to wipe the memory. You need to have a Xiaomi account linked to the phone.

https://en.miui.com/unlock/download_en.html

If the phone is recognized as unlocked then try to use the MiFlash tool and install an older rom based on your model and region.

https://cdn.alsgp0.fds.api.mi-img.com/micomm/MiFlash2020-3-14-0.rar

https://xiaomifirmwareupdater.com/miui/

If the bootloader is still unlocked you can try to go back from there and restore to factory, but if the bootloader got locked or the phone is not recognized it might not be possible to restore without going directly into the hardware.

Xiaomi phones have a built it lock that prevents flashing or modifying the OS without enabling permissions beforehand using the official apps, and the Mediatek models can get bricked by forcing the changes unlike the Snapdragon models. Hopefully this helps.

>>1301924
>what do you guys recommend?
I am gonna give you four recs split into four categories
>something that came out this year that I enjoyed
Summertime Rendering.
This is one of those rare manga adaptations that actually hit the mark and I feel it flew under a lot of peoples radar. It is a mystery/action/supernatural/thriller and the basic non spoiler plot is that MC returns to home island for the funeral of his stepsister but when he looks into it he discovers something supernatural about her death.
>something based on your favourite anime
MUSHI-SHI
Considering you like Kino, Lain, and Steins;Gate I think you would appreciate this anime. Plot is very simple: traveler named Ginko travels as a vegabond in rural 19th century Japan to solve mushi/human problems. Mushi are supernatural beings who can effect the physical world but have no physical body.
>something I would personally recommend
I really like TEXNOLYZE.
I warn this anime is not for everyone as I have seen a lot of people get filtered while saying stuff like 'it is too slow'. TEX is a cyber punk, dystopian, sci-fi, noir set in an underground world where there are multiple mob factions fighting for power of the city of Lux which is the last human city in the world. The setting alone sells it for me but I think the characters also sell it and the ending is very good too.
>something moe
Right now I am watching Yama no Susume and so far I would recommend if you are into cute girls. Plot is simple, group of high school girls develope an interest in mountain climbing and in a SoL fashion climb montains.
>this DIY one, is it any good?
I have watched 10/12 episodes and it is okay. I was honestly expecting more practical DIY stuff they would show off and on that front this show disappoints. Still it is better then most shows that aired this season as Chainsaw Man ended up being botched by a hack director.

>The characters speak a slightly different dialect of Japanese because they are islanders and the best way to translate this distinction was to use slightly slang english
So if you were translating a chinese cartoon instead of an anime, you'd give them ching-chong-chinaman so we know they're speaking chinese? If the premise is to give you the same experience as someone from tokyo would get, I reject said premise utterly. I'm from somewhere with a "slightly different dialect of english", and if someone translated our stuff into made-up french to give your average frenchman the experience an englishman or american might get when watching it, then he's failed as a translator. I don't get the experience an american would get, because I speak my dialect, and tv where I'm from is made for me, not for americans.

Anyways, subtitles in weird english are annoying because:
- I don't read the subtitles through any kind of conscious process, it just kinda happens without me having to try. Unless the subtitles are in some wacky non-english, because now I have to consciously translate it into real english then match it to the japanese sentence, and that's too much work to do in real time
- My Japanese is N3-ish, I can tell they're not speaking tokyo-ben without the subtitle team writing it in something they reckon sounds vaguely Amish
- my usual interaction with subtitles is to glance down at anything that looks complicated because it's a sign that the line's going to be complicated and the subtitles might need a bit more attention. Every line I've seen of this looks complicated when you glance at it
So anyways, that's why this kinda behaviour is annoying to me. YMMV, perhaps you're from wherever this text is supposed to be from, and it makes sense to you without you having to decode it.

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302178
>optical SPDIF input
An "optical S/PDIF" input is called a "TOSLINK input".

You need a s/pdif-to-toslink converter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302258
>>1302259
Would a 1in/2out hdmi adapter work?
Just trying to connect this settop box (single HDMI out) to a soundbar (with ARC).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302315
>to a soundbar (with ARC).
Does your TV have ARC?
If so, connect the TV's ARC HDMI port to the soundbar's HDMI port, and that should be all you need to do and the audio will automatically follow whatever source the TV is on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302315
This has come up before on /wsr/, so to nip any confusion in the bud, ARC goes backwards down the HDMI cable, so it comes out the TV's input, and in the receiver/soundbar's output. This is why it's called audio *return* channel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302315
>Would a 1in/2out hdmi adapter work?
If your TV does not support ARC, this will work and is your cleanest and cheapest option.

Unless the soundbar has s/pdif, in which case connect the two s/pdif ports with literally any phono cable. They say you need a fancy one, but you don't unless you're running it to another room.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't know what's going to work man, but I do know they can live inside your wall or mattress or somewhere else hidden that a fogger might not even reach. The fogger might not even be able kill them because of resistance to pesticides.

Find where they are living, maybe 5 feet away from where they are biting you. Put a tight cover over you bed and under so they can't crawl out of the mattress. Put a moat around your bed legs so they can't crawl up your bed. Keep any valence well off the ground so they can't climb. Try steam cleaning your whole bed. Wash your bedding in hot water and dry your bedding on high heat for a long time to kill them. They'll live in your clothes, walls, carpet and bed so good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302038
- be systematic
- define a perimeter
- do not let anything that's not been treated cross the perimeter

Buy a chest freezer and some vacuum bags. Doesn't have to be a good one, you can get it from a charity shop. Get a freezer thermometer to make sure it gets down to 0°F/-20°C. Anything you vacuum-bag and put in this freezer for four days will come out with no live bedbugs in it and can be placed inside the perimeter. For mattresses you have a few choices:
- roll them up and put them in the freezer (let them thaw before unrolling them)
- throw them away
- buy a bedbug mattress wrap and wrap them up for a year or two until all the bedbugs starve (follow directions)

>>1302038
>best way
hiring a pest control company

but in terms of diy stuff, i can tell you what worked for me when i had a flea problem:
1) get a strong vacuum; vacuum everywhere (but especially target the places where you think they're hiding, use the crevice tool attachment) and go outside when you empty the bags
2) put your clothes/bedding/etc in the dryer on high heat (20m)

unlike fleas, bedbugs won't try to cling to you/your clothing; they'll hide out elsewhere (bed frame, walls cracks, dressers etc.) until you go back to sleep

also, here's some info from a university's entomology dept:
https://entomology.ca.uky.edu/ef636

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302213
>what worked for me when i had a flea problem

Fleas are much easier to eliminate than bed bugs. Not only do they hide where pesticides can't reach, adult bed bugs can live for at least two months without feeding, commonly six months, and have been observed to live over a year without food. In extremely favourable conditions adult fleas can live for two weeks but normally only at most four days without feeding.

>>1302119
>0°F/-20°C
The super cooling point is -4 °F = -20 °C. 0 °F is -17.8 °C.

>Anything you vacuum-bag and put in this freezer for four days will come out with no live bedbugs in it

If the freezer doesn't cycle its temperature by more than a couple of degrees that should work. That's why it's important to get that conversion right because 0 °F = -17.8 °C is too close to the -16 °C given in literature and the temperature could cycle above that. Also need to have an accurate thermometer.

>>1300376
>Am I correct in thinking that as long as the motherboard has slots for everything I want that it doesn't really matter which one I go for or is there anything else I should be considering?
Processor features are now tied to what motherboard you purchased: the processor checks and disables them if you didn't pay enough.
Intel does this with overclocking: even with a K-processor, you can't fiddle with the multiplier unless you have a Z motherboard.
AMD does it with PCI Express: even though it's the CPU that generates high-speed PCIe lanes, the chipset isn't involved, and the motherboard's sole involvement is providing 40 pairs of wires, AMD processors will disable their PCIe 4.0/5.0 support if you didn't pay for at least a B550.

Anyways, what you should do is find someone who assembled a PC that they're happy with, and copy that. Or buy one from a local store.

High speed digital signals are a bitch and a half to get right.
It's not just a matter of plugging wires together.
You need them all to be right length, the right width, as well as the right distance from the ground plane and one another.
If the PCB isn't engineered for PCIe 4.0 speeds, it's just not happening.

posts.com:
youre wanting to build a win 7 machine
so you shouldnt bother with new hardware
get these parts:

XEON E3 1241 V3 for about $40

4x4GB (16GB) PC3-12800U for about $40

basically any LGA 1150 motherboard with 4 DIMM slots (ASUS Q87M-E is a good choice. used boards dont always come with the i/o shield but it doesnt really matter. make sure you update the BIOS to the latest version regardless of which brand/model you choose) for about $50-$60

get a $50 case with a mesh front panel like the DeepCool MATREXX 40

for storage i recommend getting a 500GB crucial MX500 for about $50 brand new. you can pair it with a 1TB WD Blue for another $45 (make sure its a WD10EZEX so you dont wind up with a garbage SMR drive)

youll need a pair of SATA cables. if you have some lying around then just use those. if not then buy a pair off ebay for like $3

id recommend using an intel stock cooler if you have one lying around too. you can buy one off ebay for $10 if you dont have one already. if you dont like downdraft coolers you can get tower style coolers that fit the LGA 1150 socket off ebay for about $20

i use thermal grizzly kryonaut for my thermal paste needs but you can use anything that isnt garbage. get a small tube unless you actually have a need for a lot of it

look around for power supply deals. dont buy anything with less than 500watts total capacity and no less than 80 plus bronze rated. you can usually find 80 plus gold rated 600watt power supplies for about $70 or less. cross reference every potential buy with
>https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/
to lessen the chance that youll buy a garbage unit

for the graphics card i recommend the GTX 1060 6GB. performs great in 1080p and only costs about $100 on ebay right now

for the OS i recommend using rufus to create your installation media
>https://rufus.ie/en/
it has a built in download function that allows you to download official microsoft windows ISO files, including windows 7.

Common misconception, windows is not permanently activated, it's only activated if the loader loads before it to monkey-patch your BIOS. That's why you can't have GPT or secure boot: no-one wrote a loader that can do that. For permanent activation and EFI boot, you need to patch your BIOS.

posts.sub: Why can you delete the same terms in both sides of an equation?
posts.com:
Let's say there is some equation

A+ABC=ATF+5
or whatever like that where there is the same literal in both sides. I remember you can do the next
A+ABC=ATF+5
A(1+BC)=ATF+5
You can cancel/delete the A and it gets
1+BC=TF+5
But why?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302196
>You can cancel/delete the A

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302196
>>1302198
stare at this until it makes sense

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1302196
>You can cancel/delete the A and it gets
>1+BC=TF+5
No.

You're dividing both sides by A, so you'd get
A(1+BC)=ATF+5
(A/A)(1+BC)=(A/A)TF+5/A
1(1+BC)=1(TF)+5/A
1+BC=TF+5/A
1-1+BC=TF+5/A-1
BC=TF+5/A-1

posts.sub: How do I convert webm with a small size and keep good quality?
posts.com:
I have seen some webms on /wsg/ anime threads, and some are pretty good quality and take little space.
Is it possible to do it with the "webm for retards" too?
If so, how do I do that?
I haven't touched the advanced tab, but I have tried moving the CRF and tolerance in the encoding tab (after picking variable), but I lose way too much quality if I try to move those things (I'm not even sure what those actually do).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Use VP9 and two pass encoding. Here's a ffmpeg guide, just ignore the youtube-dl part because it's been deprecated in favor of yt-dlp, also you should refrain from using -g 9999 if it results in a webm that lags when you use the seek bar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1301685
With WebM for Retards you have two options:

- Constant
Enable high quality mode: checked.
Size limit: set to 4mb for /gif/, 6mb for /wsg/ and 3mb otherwise.
Bitrate: keep blank.
Audio: enable for /gif/ and /wsg/. You can pick a low bitrate like 64kb/s for a webm where audio is not important and multiples of it for webms where music is the focus.

This will always produce a webm under the filesize limit you set, however it won't always produce the best quality it could possibly be.

- Variable
Enable high quality mode: checked
CRF: This determines the perceptive quality of the video. Depending on a number of factors such as duration, resolution, framerate, and the content itself of the video, you will produce a bigger or smaller webm. Set between 20 (best quality) and 50 (worst).
Audio: if enabled, set Quality to a range between 3 (worst) and 10 (best).

With variable, the only way to get a webm that fits within the filesize constraints of the board is through trial and error, since the encoder will not be constrained by a file size limit.
A video encoded through variable virtually always looks better than a video of the same filesize encoded through the constant bitrate method.

For both Constant and Variable enable VP9/Opus in the Advanced settings. VP9 results in a filesize 2x smaller over VP8, meaning you can fit a video of twice the quality in the same filesize, but more than doubles the encoding time.
You can also try to increase Slices, it should increase encoding time and give better quality but I've personally never noticed a difference.

Also check out these other 2 programs made for creating webms for 4chan, they have different interfaces and features:
https://github.com/Kagami/boram
https://github.com/dfaker/WebmGenerator
All of them rely on ffmpeg for the actual encoding so the settings will be similar across all the programs you use but their interface can help with editing, cropping, slicing, batch creating webms, quality presets and so on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1301685
if >>1301695 is too complicated (still worth understanding the details) try Webm For Lazys which defaults to vp9, select high quality and adjust CRF to suit.
If quality is too low, trim the length before changing the dimensions. Eg. roughly 10 seconds of 1080p should encode to 3 MB, 30 seconds of 720p to 3MB (no sound). very dependent on source, sometimes I get good quality 50 second encodes of 1080p to fit 6 MB.
Another guide (old): justpaste DOT it SLASH 6nvv0

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One of the most important points wasn't mentioned - downscale your videos. 720p has only half the pixels of 1080p, and about half the file size, while 480p is about 4x smaller. Most of good encoding boils down to 'avoid stupid shit' like trying to cram hour-long videos to 3mb.

480p and crf 30 - 36 should get you 'good enough' videos for most things, at least for smartphone viewing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1301765
There is that orange oil type of glue remover. It's even been sold at the dollar store (before Biden inflation priced those products out of stock). I bought some at Lowe's although any hardware store will carry it.

If you only have small amounts of sticky residue here and there, use sticky tape to remove it. Depending on the type and age of the residue, different types of tape may work or fail. If tape fails, then you'll have to go the "glue be gone" solvent route.

Wash your hands. They must be non-oily. Dirty hands ruin the stickiness of the tape. Get some tape about three inches long. Gently and even press the end of the tape over the residue. Now pull the tape away from the surface at a 90 degree angle to the surface (perpendicular). Some of the residue will stick to tape. You may need to do it several times before the residue loosens enough to be pulled off. If this works, repeat until the residue is gone. Once you get the hang of the method, you can use shorter pieces of tape as your skill improves.

If the peropendicular method doesn't work well, note that some types of residue are gummy. These can be removed by the "oblique" method. Gently press about 3/4 to one inch of the tape to the residue. Now hold the tape about 20 to 30 degrees angle to the surface. While very gently pressing down on the tape touching the residue, with the other hand pull the tape sideways while maintaining that 20 to 30 degree angle. Repeat several times as the residue loosens and finally lets go.

If you use orange oil (goo be gone), wipe the surface clean with a cleaner such as windex when done. Not all plastics are compatible with orange oil so wiping it off is good practice.

>>1301653
>What should I put for my
>>first given name
>>other given names
>the form asks me for a preferred given name and a surname, which I filled in.
Just treat it as a list:
Item zero (patronymic name) goes into "first given name"
Item n (surname) goes into "surname"
Everything in the middle (personal name, surname) goes into "other given names"

Then use the "preferred names" bit to tell people what you use.
